title: drivers-blocking-county-coastal-roads-asked-think-others
story: East Lothianrsquos scenic coastline has been flooded with visitors from throughout the county and beyond since lockdown restrictions were relaxed at the end of last month.However, with cars lining many roads, Dunbar Coastguard have urged people to be more considerate.Teams of Coastguard volunteers from throughout East Lothian have spent recent weekends carrying out ldquoaccident prevention surveillance patrols.A spokesman for the Dunbar crew said: ldquoDespite local media attention recently, cars were found to be obstructing coastal access roads that may be needed by emergency services.ldquoWhilst it is nice to enjoy our beautul coastline now that lockdown restrictions have eased, please think of others and consider the consequences of your actions.ldquoFurther preventative patrols will be considered in the coming weeks, taking into account any changes to lockdown restriction, weather conditions and any particular hazards we are made aware of.ldquoIf you see someone in dficulty or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, beaches, clfs, mud or water, call  immediately and ask for the Coastguard.

title: phase-2-13-new-changes-scotlands-lockdown-restrictions-eased

but should continue meeting outdoors.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside - with the maximum of  extra households and  people.This is in addition to the measures from Phase , which included sunbathing sitting outdoors, and visiting other households outdoors and in gardens.Extended householdFrom tomorrow, people who live alone or with children under  can have a bubble with one other household - you can visit indoors and stay overnight.This has to be with this household onlyTransportPublic transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.Face masks will be mandatory on all public transport.The First Minister says the five mile limit for leisure and recreational purposes will remain for now - "remain as close as possible to local area" until Phase There is no five-mile limit for visiting family and friends.DentistsAll dental practices can reopen to see patients with urgent care needs from Phase  ndash meanwhile procedures which generate aerosols will remain at emergency dental hubs.SportsThe guidance also says the resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is allowed.As with the previous Phase, unrestricted outdoors exercise is permitted, so long as you adhere to distancing measures. Non-contact sports like golf, hiking, fishing etc remain allowed.However, gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .WorshipThe route map also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans fornon-essential retail units to reopen form June - but these will have to have outside entrances. Therefore shopping centres cannot reopen.Drive-thrus and garden centres were already permitted to reopen under the previous easing of measures.SportsSports courts and playgrounds are now permitted to reopen across Scotland.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.MarriagesUnder Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with the number of attendees kept to a minimal.Moving houseRelaxation on restrictions on housing moves.EducationCollege and university staff canto make essential preparations for restart in Phase .These institutionswill not until Phase , with schools set toacross Scotland from August .

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown

jobs are on the line after the UK arm of retailer Victorias Secret collapsed into administration.Around  stores are at risk after the lingerie retailer called in Deloitte for a light touch administration after being hit by the closure of stores during thecoronaviruscrisis.InScotland, the brands flagship store is on Glasgows Buchanan Street, meaning jobs within the city centre are at risk.The store in Buchanan Street opened in  in the place of Buchanan Galleries former HM premises, after previously opening a shop in Glasgow Airport in .MonsoonCity locations: Silverburn and store leases.He will hope to save as many as  stores and , jobs.The firm announced the news in June.:Monsoon enters administration threatening over  job lossesQuizCity locations:Buchanan Street, St firm.Fashion chain Quiz is placing the ision that runs its  standalone stores into administration as part of a restructure to offload loss-making outlets and slash its rent bill.The group said  of the  staff affected by the decision will remain with the group but that  jobs are at risk.Quiz will look to buy back the stock and some of the assets from the Kast ision placed in administration for pound. million so it can try to renegotiate better rents with landlords on some of the stores with a view to keeping them open.:Glasgow fashion chain Quiz puts property arm in administration with  jobs at risk

title: we-lost-dad-cant-mum-yet-p-k-thinks-can-drive-269-miles-babysitter-glasgow-reacts-dominic-cummings

He was helping lead the Covid response. He had thousands of peoplesrsquo lives in his hand. He was also dealing with a sick we and a child. He had to be available. He took them to be cared for then he got ill.ldquoSurely we are big enough to realise that exceptions need to be made for the man who had the b***s to shoulder the responsibility which millions would run from.ldquoGive the guy a break and donrsquot harasses him when he has his wee boy there!Liz Cassidy said: ldquoHe should have stayed home with his we and child. title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  George Square needs to be completely overhauled - here   s why
story: The new station completely transforms the look and feel of this part of town. What a shame, then, about the second thing I couldnrsquot help noticing: how drab and disappointing George Square remains.Granted, the grim sight of loyalist protesters wrapped in Union flags ldquoprotecting the statues and Cenotaph didnrsquot help. But even without their isive presence the cityrsquos historic square is a let-down, visually, socially and culturally, a frustrating waste of urban space that could and should be far better utilised.Where other European squares create buzz and atmosphere with year-round arts, culture, food and shopping attracting locals and visitors, George Square is dreary and uninspiring: a few trees, some benches and a clutch of dull, predictable th-century statues ndash ldquogreat men and Queen Victoria ndash that few feel any kinship with. The only part of the square that has any real purpose and meaning is the Cenotaph.The idea that George Square is in serious need of a makeover is nothing new, of course, and there have been ious  dawns and broken promises over the years, not least the outrageous fiasco of  ndash remember that  ndash which wasted huge amounts of public money and goodwill alike. But the two defining events of  - coronavirus and the Black Lives Matter protests -offer Glasgow the best opportunity in a generation to finally get this right and transform George Square into the vibrant civic centre Glaswegians deserve.Letrsquos start with the pandemic, which will continue to damage the economic and social pull of town and city centres. As lockdown restrictions are gradually lted we will grasp a new reality ndash fewer shops, restaurants, bars and cultural attractions than before, with those that do re-open unable to work at full capacity for now. Answers to the sort of questions around attracting people to city centres that were already stumping businesses, planners and local authorities even before coronavirus hit have become all the more pressing.Thatrsquos where a proper revamp of George Square comes in, a key step forward in boosting Glasgowrsquos economy and cultural capital in the wake of the pandemic. What should the square contain  That would be for citizens to decide, but herersquos a few quick ideas that presume an eventual end to social distancing: an ampitheatre for live music, theatre and comedy, proper seating, pop-up pods for community groups, a food and craft market, arts and exhibition space, murals, a garden and childrenrsquos play area.As for the fate of the statues, again, it would be for the people to decide whether they still have a place in this new urban realm. Not that we would want to forget our past, of course. But surely we can find new and more creative ways to confront, commemorate and celebrate it, taking in voices that were previously ignored ndash women, ethnic minorities, working class people, gay people, the disabled ndash reflecting the ersity of our city as it is now.Rather than an expensive international competition for designs ndash letrsquos learn from  ndash a three-month public consultation could be held, and a  of local architects, planners, artists, businesspeople and community groups convened to create perhaps three dferent plans, which would then be voted on by the people of Glasgow. Granted, such an ambitious revamp wouldnrsquot be easy to fund in the dficult years ahead, but with a crucial economic and culturalat stake, it should be prioritised. Surely a mixture of public, private and philanthropic funding could be sourced Glasgow City Council has already started the conversation that could make all this happen, by bringing forward the pedestrianisation of George Square and suspending a third of city centre parking bays to make room for walkers and cyclists.I would urge council leader Susan Aitken and her team to think bigger. A commitment to redesign George Square would offer an exciting, positive and inclusive focus for Glaswegians in the tough months ahead. The end result could be what Glasgow has been crying out for for a generation: a proud and modern civic centrepiece that is worthy of our great city, a place that excites, entertains, and educates, that makes us feel part of something bigger. Wersquove never needed it more.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  Swinney s school plan is not so much blended as half-baked
story: I donrsquot think this latter-day Rousseau really believed deschooling would actually happen. But in Scotland, thanks to Covid it could be within sight. Schoolrsquos out, not just for summer but for the foreseeable future.At least that was the educational prognosis from the Deputy First Minister, John Swinney, at the weekend. He announced a new ldquoblended learning, which sounds like something to do with tea, but is a euphemism for Scottish children spending most of the school week at home.:Opinion: Brian Beacom: Why I am edging slowly towards the pro-independence point of viewParents in Edinburgh were told that, when schools go back on August , theyrsquoll be lucky to see their children getting face-to-face teaching for a third of the time. Many Scottish pupils might only get one day a week. This is not so much blended as half-baked.Mr Swinney also endorsed the view of Larry Flanagan, general-secretary of the teachers union the EIS, that next yearrsquos exam diet should be cancelled, like this yearrsquos. Few in the education establishment much like competitive exams at the best of time, so it might seem unsurprising that they have been dropped ndash for the first time since .Parents, who donrsquot seem to have been consulted by Mr Swinneyrsquos misnamed Education Recovery Group, are furious. They see this as an abdication of responsibility by bureaucrats who care nothing about educational attainment and are putting the interests of their own client groups above the welfare of children.Parents in Edinburgh formed an instant pressure group,  , to demand proper, face-to-face education at least  per cent of the week. Sarah Chisnall says they also want serious benchmarked online learning for the other part of the ldquoblended learning experience, with a regular amount of teacher face time.Three months into school lockdown, it is surely a scandal that nothing of the like has been done. Home schooling is practically non-existent in many areas, according to parents, with some children having no contact with anything remotely resembling an actual teacher on line. Google, FIFA  and Instagram are poor substitutes.A UK-wide study from University College London confirmed yesterday that two million children across Britain have done little or no schoolwork at home during the lockdown. Four million have not had regular contact with a teacher and six million have not ed their most recent assignment.Nicola Sturgeon, who recognises a political disaster when she sees one, leaped in to try to undo the damage done by her deputy. ldquoIt is absolutely not the case that we are planning on blended learning to last a year or anything like it, she said on Monday, giving no guarantees that it wonrsquot.The First Minister promised that face-to face-teaching will happen ldquoas soon as possible. Exams will go ahead ndash well maybe ndash and she hinted that the two-metre rule in social distancing might be relaxed in schools.ldquoDelusional. said the SNPrsquos sometime coalition partners, the Scottish Greens, which has a lot of teachers amongst its membership. Like Larry Flanagan of the EIS they think next yearrsquos exams should be cancelled because there is no safe way of preparing children for them.Tell that to the parents. We know that the risk to children is vanishingly small. To prevent pupils spreading the disease to teachers and parents, schools could use masks, hand sanitisers, ldquobubble cohorts, and perspex screens.It is not aschildren arenrsquot associating already out of school. The extra transmission risk from a deep-cleaned environment like a school must surely be negligible. The risks of not going to school ndash mental health, obesity, domestic abuse and the like ndash are almost certainly greater than the risk of Covid.:Coronavirus: Push to prescribe vitamin D to people at highest risk from Covid in bid to curb second wave of virusParents say, rightly, that the two metre rule is not enforced in hospitals. It manestly isnrsquot in supermarkets, parks and public transport either. So why is this bureaucratic red line being applied in schools Why is the education of their children not a priority, they say  With classes and schools only able to handle a third of children, the obvious answer is to increase the number of classrooms and the number of teachers.Break out of the school precincts and start deploying unused venues like cinemas and churches, even marquees. Bring in supply teachers and retired teachers to bump up the numbers.It would of course mean more than the pound million or so in additional funding the Government is currently offering the local authorities. But the Scottish education and skills budget is more than pound. billion. Surely some of that could be reallocated, as was the case in the NHS when they set up ldquopop-up hospitals like the Louisa Jordan.At any rate, Nicola Sturgeon now has a major fight on her hands. The EIS says, correctly, that the two-metre rule is still what the Governmentrsquos scientic advisers say is necessary to prevent a second wave of Covid-. They are not going to sht on that, eventhe World Health Organisation has been talking about reducing it to one metre.There are two million parents out there and only , teachers. Ms Sturgeon can do her political arithmetic. She is going to have to spray some serious cash to get the schools back on any kind of ing basis.Scottish teachers got a  per cent pay hike from the Government last year. I suspect Mr Swinney is going to have to loosen the purse strings again to prevent the deschooling of a generation of Scottish children.The late Ivan Illich, whose thinking influenced the Curriculum for Excellence, envisaged children teaching themselves, using technology, even though he was writing before the internet existed. He would be proud to see the nationrsquos youth gathering around their screens. Unfortunately, parents arenrsquot ndash especiallyit means they lose their chances of educational qualications.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-seeds-division-sown-long-rise-snp
story: In his pejorative letter against Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP Mr Bone claims that "most of us were relatively content and secure" before the existence of the SNP. How can he possibly substantiate such a statement  Has he forgotten the years of rule under Margaret Thatcher and the social ision created under her tenure as Prime Minister  He has obviously conveniently overlooked the ision in the UK over the Iraq War brought to us by Tony Blair. Democracy is nothing,it is not about peaceful debate, ideas and dare I say, ision.Alec Oattes, Ayr.GIRVAN must be a really nice place. David Bone seems to have missed the British and Irish nationalists marching every year in Scotland, throughout my three score years and ten. Orange and green colours to the fore, they claim it ldquopart of their culture. These marches pre-date any signicance the SNP had in Scotland: indeed it was the Unionist Party Scotland which promoted Orange-ism in the s. We saw these ldquoLoyalists in all their glory on Sunday.There have also been literally dozens of riots in England in my letime, many of them rooted in identity and race, not one related to the SNP.Mr Bone also misses the fact that the SNP wishes to normalise Scotland as a self-governing country, while opposition to that seems based on a British nationalist identikit contrivance. Unionist parties have taken turns over the last century and more, of at first supporting Scottish home rule, then deriding it. If at any point, say with the ldquoScottish Covenant in  , they had attempted to seriously meet Scottish democratic aspirations, then Mr Bone would be sleeping more happily in his bed.Now itrsquos probably too late many Scots no longer trust Unionists donrsquot believe in a Prime Minister who has repeatedly made disparaging remarks about Scots and Scotland find majority Scottish opinions commonly discounted and ignored.GR Weir, Ochiltree.NO doubt there will be many comments about David Bonersquos letter about the SNP supposedly engineering ldquoisive identity politics". I would argue that the Establishment in England, especially in Whitehall, has been doing that since the birth of the United Kingdom.As a schoolboy in  I asked why the new queen was titled Queen Elizabeth the Second of Great Britain. The answer was that she accepted that proposal when made in Whitehall. Thirty-four years later a British team first won the European Cup. Jock Stein was only given a lowly honour because of classdistinction by Whitehall directive.How often does radio and television media refer to Manchester being in the North although these media supposedly relate to the whole of the British Isles  Even in quizzes, questions such as "how many lions are on the Royal Standard" or "which organisation is responsible for lighthouses and navigation aids" have only the answers referring to England accepted  Newspaper reviews almost never include those of The Herald or other Scottish papers.The current issue of the History Scotland magazine relates atthe dficulties in forming international rules, for both rugby and football, for the home nations. For several years the English administrators wanted the other nations to accept only those of England. Even the first Scottish rugby team to play against England was picked in England.The question of more anger in the last decade and months arises from Brexit, Nigel Farage and Boris Johnson. These have virtually ignored the Scottish majority.Hate is too strong a word, butit does occur then it should be directed at the arrogance of the English establishment and Whitehall, not at our neighbouring nations as a whole. I am sure that many Scots have English friends and relations with whom we continue to socialise ndash providing that we get to air our own views.JB Drummond, Kilmarnock.THE SNPrsquos call for more funding from Westminster is baffling.Coming from the administration whose financial "expertisersquorsquo has led to two rusting hulks on a Scottish shipyardrsquos stocks, at the cost of hundreds of millions, and, with exquisite timing for a pandemic, a white elephant airport. Vanity projects they most certainly were.And that is only for starters. I have not even mentioned unfinished hospitals.Giving the SNP Government more money would be akin to giving Dracula the keys to the blood bank.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.Read more: Letters: SNP paved the way for the isive identity politics we see today

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  The Kirk s plan to banish the elderly from services is cruel  There   s no other word for it
story: The crassness of such advice beggars belief. Surely this age group can assess the risks for itself  If pews were packed as full as the Cheltenham races it might just about be defensible. Few services, however, attract high numbers. Most congregations could have upheld social distancing throughout the pandemic with no fear of catching anything worse than a cold from the draught whistling among them.:Push to prescribe vitamin D to people at highest risk from Covid in bid to curb second wave of virusMore importantly, the vast majority of the Kirkrsquos most devoted and loyal followers are over . Some will be dedicated, le-long attenders others will have reached retirement before making time to think about faith, and the search for the meaning of le.I have countless friends in their seventies and eighties who are fitter and sharper than many younger folk. It seems invidious to talk of them as a universally frail category perhaps they are better described as having reached a point when there is much less road ahead than in the rear view mirror. Yet, regardless of physical condition, by this stage spiritual sustenance and solace become more pressing and meaningful. Equally comforting is the companionship and consolation of a like-minded community.Brought up as I was in a devout Church of Scotland family, I saw the importance for older members of the routine, ritual and contact weekly services offered. Remembering some of our church-going friends, people of inspiring kindness and integrity, it is deeply upsetting to think that it is iniduals like them, to whom the church owes its very existence, who are being sidelined and devalued. The idea of banishing the elderly, of consigning them to a Zoom link or a virtual coffee morning until the virus has fled, is cruel. Therersquos no other word for it. Those for whom technology is intimidating, confusing, or a second-rate stop-gap, will be left stranded.To withdraw all prospect of real human contact is particularly egregious at a time like this. For months, the -plus have been living in near isolation and confinement, bombarded with terrying news and statistics, and unable to see family or friends. Imprisoned as they have been at home, for them the church represents a calm, still centre during the storm. Many will have been longing to get back into their place of worship, but will now be worried they are not entirely welcome. It doesnrsquot get much more hurtful than that.As well as being harsh, the Kirkrsquos attitude is also short-sighted. Dwindling as its resources are, it relies heavily on bequests. For some parishioners, as they approach old age it is important to know they will continue to contribute to the Church of Scotlandrsquos work, long after they have gone. Their legacies are priceless, not to say essential, but they should not be taken for granted. Codicils and rewrites take minutes.:Bosses warning as Scotland races ahead of other UK nations in unemploymentRegardless of the financial contribution older members have already made, to treat them so negligently is heartless. Of course nobody should fall ill because of attending a Sunday service, butsafety procedures are followed, it will be no more dangerous ndash arguably less so ndash than any other venture or visit.In showing such caution and cowardice, the Kirk has forgotten the principles on which it was founded: it is a Christian duty to tend the sick, befriend the lonely, and to nurture every believerrsquos spirit. This latest salvo smacks more of health and safety or fear of litigation than le-giving care and compassion. The Kirk has never been more necessary for all its members, butever there was a statement of its redundancy, this letter is it.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: Should Nicola Sturgeon be next in line for the Connolly documentary treatment
story: Yet Billy and Us, part of a Connolly season on BBC Scotland, has proven to be one of the new channelrsquos biggest hits.The first two episodes on May  and  chalked up higher viewing in Scotland than anything  on BBC Two, Channels Four or Five.With the repeat on Sundays, the episodes have had , viewers each week, with more than , requests for the series on BBC iPlayer.A case of Connollyrsquos magic touch, or is the ldquoBilly and Us format a winning idea that could be applied to other prominent Scots Dr Andy Dougan, lecturer in film and television studies at The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, praised Billy and Us for its ldquoclever and imaginative use of material.: Billy Connolly on pathetic Scottish LabourEach episode featured Connolly watching excerpts from past interviews and performances and reflecting on them, and le in general.Other interviewees, including fellow performers Elaine C Smith and Janey Godley, set out what Connolly meant to them in the context of the times.ldquoClip shows are very often hackneyed old pieces of often seen film with quotes from people who barely knew the subject, said Dr Dougan.ldquoBilly and Us was genuinely reflective, both for him and the audience, and the footage reminded us of how much the comedy scene owes to Billy Connolly.Billy and Us was made by BBC Studios Documentary Unit, the department responsible for other recent successes including last yearrsquos Thatcher: A Very British Revolution and Louis Theroux, Le And Death Row.Connolly was the ideal subject for such an in-depth portrait because there is so much footage of him spanning the decades. As Scotland changed, so Connolly changed. Much of the delight of the series lay in glimpses of the old Glasgow, of dogs wandering the streets and women leaning on window sills, watching the world go by.The choice of Connolly was key to the success of the films, said Dr Dougan.ldquoItrsquos hard to think of a more signicant and unying cultural figure in the past  years.Yet he agreed there were other prominent Scots whose story mirrors Scotlandrsquos, and who have enough treasures in the archive waiting to be dusted off or discovered.: Why Ill never apologise over religion routineCandidates for the ldquoBilly and Us treatment might include: Fergie and Us Why: At , Sir Alex Ferguson is a year older than Connolly. They both have a link to the shipyards: Ferguson Snr worked there, as did Connolly. Sir Alex and Sir Billy typy the working class, self-educated generation of Glaswegians who went out in the world to make their names and fortunes. Sir Alexrsquos success with Aberdeen and Manchester United makes him a regular on any list of the best football managers of all time.TV highlights: Lting the European Cup Winnersrsquo Cup , winning the UEFA Champions League .Nicola and Us Why: First Minister of Scotland, and first woman in the job, Nicola Sturgeonrsquos rise through the ranks has coincided with fundamental changes in Scotlandrsquos political landscape. From devolution to independence referendum and beyond, the -year-old and Scotland have come of age together. She was facing a critical point in her career, the push for a second referendum, when the greatest health crisis of the age hit.TV highlights: The formal stuff, meeting Ministers and the Queen, but the informal too, including the moment she was voted in as FM with her then eight-ear-old niece, Harriet, watching from the gallery of the Scottish Parliament.Andy and Us Why: Double winner of Wimbledon, greatest ever British tennis player. Travelled the world from a young age, survived baptism of fire from Englandrsquos press to become the darling of Murray Mound. Husband, father, feminist, Murray has been as smart off the court as on, investing his fortune in ventures such as Cromlix Hotel. Still in his early thirties, where does he see Scotlandrsquos future TV highlights: First Wimbledon victory when he sank to his knees in a mixture of exhaustion, relief, and sheer joy.Sean and Us Why: Going from Edinburgh milkman to the first and best Bond, and an Oscar winner to boot, surely merits a place in any Scottish documentary hall of fame. Born in Edinburgh in , Sean Connery is another working class Scot made knight of the realm. Approaching his th birthday, could have plenty to say about his long career and his equally y support for Scottish independence.TV highlights: Anything from Bond, plus his speech in The Untouchables . Appearances at the Edinburgh International Film Festival.Clare and Us Why: At first glance, Clare Grogan might seem a stretch for a six part series. Why not fellow actor Kelly Macdonald, who has worked with the Coen brothers and Martin Scorsese  But born in the early s, Grogans experience of growing up in Scotland would chime with that of many another baby boomer. Then there is her starring role in Gregoryrsquos Girl, still regarded by many as the best Scottish movie ever, and her successful career as the lead singer in Altered Images.TV highlights: The dancing on the grass scene from Gregorrsquos Girl, singing Happy Birthday on Top of the Pops.On the possibility of a series on another prominent Scot, a BBC spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore always looking for new ways to highlight notable people of Scotland, both famous and those less well known.Billy and Us, BBC Scotland, tonight, pm, and iPlayerNews from trusted and credible sources is essential at all times, but especially now as the coronavirus pandemic impacts on all aspects of our lives. To make sure you stay informed during this dficult time our coverage of the crisis is free.However, producing The Heralds unrivalled analysis, insight and opinion on a daily basis still costs money and, as our traditional revenue streams collapse, we need your support to sustain our quality journalism.To help us get through this, wersquore asking readers to take a digital subscription to The Herald. You can sign up now for just pound for two months.If you choose to sign up, wersquoll offer a faster loading, advert-light experience ndash and deliver a digital version of the print product to your device every day. Click here to help The Herald: Thank you, and stay safe.

title: nicola-sturgeon-reveals-hopes-staycation-next-month-celebrate-birthday
story: The First Minister said she is also keen to see more of her family when coronavirus lockdown restrictions are gradually lted.A further easing of Covid- rules is expected to be announced tomorrow, including allowing greater social interaction.Phase two could also pave the way for the reopening of smaller shops, some factories and other non-office indoor workplaces.Meanwhile, pubs and restaurants could be able to open outdoor areas.Hospitality and tourism businesses, such as hotels and the indoor areas of pubs and restaurants, have been told to prepare to reopen on July .Ms Sturgeon spoke of her hopes during a radio interview on Capital Scotland Drive with Katy J.She was asked where she will head when lockdown is relaxed, andshe had any Munros she wanted to bag.The First Minister said: ldquoI think Irsquod have to do a bit of training and get a bit fitter than I am just nowI was to try and bag a Munro, but who knows.ldquoSo, when Irsquom able to, seeing more of my family is obviously something Irsquom keen to do.ldquoIt was quite dficult going to see my mum and dad on Sunday because my sister lives close by but I could only see one other household so I had to choose my mum and dad over my sister, which as you can imagine, didnrsquot go down very well.ldquoSo being able to see them together is something I really looking forward to, eventhat is outside.ldquoAnd, you know, obviously when hopefully from about the middle of July we are able to allow the tourist industry to open up again, then supporting the Scottish tourist industry, maybe getting away for a weekend.ldquoBecause around about that time I will also celebrate a particular birthday and also my tenth wedding anniversary so my husband ndashhersquos listening ndash can take this as a hint that we need to support the tourist industry.ldquoHe needs to support the tourist industry by arranging some kind of small staycation for me.Ms Sturgeon is married to Peter Murrell, the chief executive of the SNP.Elsewhere, the First Minister said visiting her parents,Robin and Joan, for the first time in months over the weekend was ldquoodd, but in a nice way.She said: ldquo I hadnrsquot seen them ndash like most people ndash for a while, probably about three months so it felt a bit odd being with people, even my mum and dad, that I hadnrsquot seen for ages.ldquoBut it was nice, it was quite brief and it was in the garden - thankfully it was a nice night and the rain stayed off.ldquoIn fact, it was quite warm, so yeah it was nice but hopefully Irsquoll get to spend a bit more time with them over the weeks to come.She previously shared a post on her Instagram page of the meeting, including a picture of both of her parents in their garden.The First Minister said decisions on a further easing of lockdown restrictions will be announced tomorrow.She said: ldquoI donrsquot think wersquore going to immediately see a lting of the advice to people to stay quite local for leisure and recreation but of course you can travel longer than that right now to see family, but up until now of course wersquove been saying to people ndash and I would imagine this will continue ndash to stay outdoorsyou see people in another household and donrsquot go indoors even to use the toilet.ldquoSo thatrsquos something wersquore looking at, can we ease that particular restriction.ldquoBecause that would make it more possible I guess for you to make the trip to Aberdeen to see your mum,you were able to use the toilet. So we want to make these things easier.ldquoNow the really important thing Irsquove got to stress is wersquove got to still be very careful, because although numbers of cases of the virus and thankfully numbers of people dying or getting very ill with it are declining quite rapidly, it hasnrsquot gone away. Itrsquos still out there.ldquoWe see in other countries right now ndash China is dealing with a new outbreak, some parts of America are seeing cases going up again.ldquoSo itrsquos still a big danger and that means wersquove still got to be careful and take things step by step, which actually it gets harder for me to persuade people of that the more we see levels of the infection reduce, but actually it continues to be really important that we donrsquot get reckless and take too many steps too quickly that then allows it to spread again.During the Capital Scotland radio show Ms Sturgeon was also asked how she looks after her own mental and emotional wellbeing.She said: ldquoItrsquos been dficult I guess over the last wee while because I have been so busy trying to deal with this day by day but Irsquove got a great husband at home who, you know, helps to look after me and make sure Irsquom not getting too stressed out about things.ldquoAnd I suppose, every now and again, Irsquove just tried to take a step back and try to focus on the positives, which during a time like this is not easy to do but there have been positives out of this.ldquoI think the sense of collective and community spirit that we found over the past three months has been really inspiring.ldquoWersquove all done the right thing not just for ourselves but for each other and I hope as we come out of the crisis and get back to normal, we donrsquot lose all of that, that we actually remember that, you know, whether itrsquos enjoying spending a bit more time with immediate family in your own household, or just getting off the treadmill a little bit for some people, that we just remember what really matters in le. Our family matters, having good health matters and community and looking out for each other matters and we should try and hold on to all of these thingsAsked what music she listens to after a long day at work, she admitted she was a a ldquohopeless s person.

title: snp-ministers-underspent-budget-250m-covid-arrived
story: Finance Secretary Kate Forbes told MSPs that the provisional outturn figures for   showed a provisional fiscal outturn of pound.bn, against a budget of around pound.bn.The resulting ldquocash iance was poundm markedly down from poundm in   and poundm for  .However the Scottish Tories said it remained a "huge" figure, and questioned why the SNP was now demanding more borrowing powers from Westminster when it was underspending and not using its borrowing powers in full.The Scottish Parliament is not legally allowed to over-spend its budget.Ms Forbes said the figure showed ldquoprudent budget management was enabling the Scottish Government to maximise its response to the coronavirus pandemic.She said the   Provisional Budget Outturn represented a . per cent underspend on a total budget of pound.bn ndash down from . per cent the previous year.All of the poundm cash underspend has been carried forward and most already deployed.She said it included poundm of fiscal resource for day-to-day spending, poundm of fiscal capital, and poundm of financial transactions which can only be used for loans and equity investment outside the public sector.She said the fiscal resource was ldquomarginally less than the poundm anticipated because of a need to ert extra funds money in the early response to the Covid outbreak.She also that as well as the cash underspend there was a ldquonon-cash underspend of poundm involving technical accounting adjustments that cannot be spent on services.Were using every penny of that poundm to combat coronavirus this year. Careful budget management last year enabled us to better fund our response to the crisis this year. Incidentally, I can confirm we wont be sending any of it back to Westminster like Scottish Labour used to. https:t.co TOCYqqyJdMs Forbes also said Scottish Government capital borrowing was poundm less than the poundm originally planned last year, while the poundm collected from the Scottish Landfill and Land and Buildings Transactions taxes were the highest since they were were fully devolved.She said: ldquoThe Scottish Government spent more than % of our budget in   on the delivery of public services and supporting the economy.ldquoOur sensible financial management has provided us with additional flexibility to deal with the effects of Covid- and the sustained and damaging post-Brexit economic uncertainty.ldquoWe will continue to maintain a firm grip on Scotlandrsquos public finances and do all we can to protect Scotlandrsquos economy and ensure that, as a country, we are back on our feet as quickly and as safely as possible.ldquoWe have very limited room for manoeuvre within our budget, which is why I will continue to make the case to the UK Government for both an increase in funding and flexibility to allow the Scottish Government to respond fully to the Covid- crisis.Scottish Tory finance spokesman Donald Cameron said: "I note that the Scottish Government borrowed pound million less in - than planned and is not therefore using existing borrowing powers to the full."With that in mind, can I ask the Cabinet Secretary why she is demanding further borrowing powers at the very moment that her Government is not only underspending to the tune of a quarter of a billion pounds but isnt even spending the existing borrowing capacity it has "Ms Forbes said: "I have repeatedly made clear that it is revenue borrowing powers that I am looking for, we have existing borrowing powers for capital."The Finance Secretary went on to say the impact of some construction projects being shelved in March due to coronavirus led to a decrease in the amount of capital borrowing being used.She added powers being granted to Scotland to borrow for its resource budget will help to offset the impact of income tax reconciliations - which are caused by forecasting mistakes - in the coming years, expected to cost poundmnext year and poundmthe following year.Both Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie and Scottish Liberal Democrats leader Willie Rennie pressed the Finance Secretary on spending in the transport sector.She said she wasin discussionswith Transport Secretary Michael Matheson about funding as Scotland emerges from lockdown, as well as reiterating her support for free bus travel for under-s, a policy bargained for by the Greens during the budget process.Mr Rennie asked Ms Forbes what she will do to "effectively deliver" the transport budget, after it was found to have the biggest underspend for the second year in a row.She committed to reinvest capital underspends because of delays to construction in the economic revival after coronavirus, adding she will "reposition the economy" to ensure it s in a "more sustainable" and "fairer" way.Three Labour MSPs asked Ms Forbesany of the underspend would be used to give schools extra resources for theof pupils in August, but she refused to say.Labour finance spokesperson Jackie Baillie said: "Given the underspend is poundm, which is carried forward to this financial year, and Nicola Sturgeon has promised schools will get all the resources they need, the Scottish Government should put its money where its mouth is and allocate a portion of this money to fund theto schools."It is unacceptable for the Finance Secretary to refuse to address this constructive suggestion when it was raised three times by Labour MSPs.ldquoKate Forbess triple dodge cant hide the fact that Scotland is now facing a triple crisis of public health, education and the economy."Once again we are seeing a total lack of joined-up thinking from the SNP government. Nicola Sturgeon claims to be on top of the crisis facing our education system, but her government is still in denial about the urgency of addressing it."

title: tough-decisions-ahead-cairngorm-following-years-financial-struggle
story: Caroline Gardner, the Auditor General for Scotland, said the coronavirus pandemic ldquoincreases the uncertainty around the costs and business model required for the mountain in the longer-term.Audit Scotland also called on the Scottish Government to ldquoexamine the long-term sustainability of the snow sports industry in Scotland.:We dont want your money - Shetland protests as SSE presses ahead with the UKs biggest wind farmIt follows long-running problems at the ski resort.Highlands and Islands Enterprise , a government agency, has had to step in to save it twice in the last ten years after external operators ran into financial dficulties.A new report by Audit Scotland said this ldquoraises serious questions about the sustainability of the business operating under the current model.HIE is the owner and custodian of Cairngorm Mountain, and has been responsible for its management for almost  years.However the private sector has operated the ski area for much of this time via a lease agreement.Cairngorm Mountain Ltdpreviously operated the business but struggled financially and was taken into public ownership in .In , HIE transferred the operation of Cairngorm Mountain to Natural Assets Investments Limited , which took full ownership of CML.But in September , the funicular railway ndash installed in  as part of a wider strategy to regenerate the Aviemore area ndash was closed after a routine inspection revealed structural issues, and shortly afterwards CML directors placed the company into administration.HIE again stepped in to take over the business, securing the assets and setting up Cairngorm MountainLimitedas a new subsidiary company to operate the mountain resort.Audit Scotland said it had "made progress in addressing some of the issues that arose under CML", but noted the new body generated an income of pound, between December  and the end of March , against expenditure of pound,, leaving it with a deficit of pound,.HIE is currently entangled in two legal cases ndash one relating to financial guarantees provided by NAIL and its majority shareholder, and the other concerning design and build aspects of the funicular railway.It hopes to reinstate the railway at an indicative cost of between pound million and poundm, however its plans have been delayed by the Covid- pandemic.It is also working on a masterplan for the long-term future of Cairngorm Mountain.Audit Scotlandrsquos report said local businesses and community representatives ldquoemphasised the importance of the resort in contributing to an economy that is heavily dependent on tourism.It added: ldquoIt is vitally important that HIE and the Scottish Government considers carefully the funding requirements for any future operating model, how costs will be met, and the opportunity costs of continued investment in Cairngorm Mountain and the wider snow sports industry.ldquoAny future decisions, including whether public subsidies are necessary to continue operations, must take into account not only the economic benefits that the resort can bring to the Badenoch and Strathspey area but also the community, social and environmental impacts of continuing operations.Ms Gardner said: ldquoHIE and the Scottish Government now face tough decisions on how to secure a sustainable operation at Cairngorm Mountain. The Covid- pandemic increases the uncertainty around the costs and business model required for the mountain in the longer-term.: Scottish transport giant faces legal bill after losing court case against GovernmentldquoAny future spending decisions need to be informed by the wide range of groups with an interest in the mountain.Rural Economy and Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing welcomed the report and said its recommendations are in line with a government review carried out in . He said: ldquoCairngorm Mountain is an important natural asset and one which has the potential to provide signicant input to the Scottish economy.ldquoThe snow sports industry is an essential part of Scotlandrsquos rural economy, worth an estimated poundm per year and providing over  jobs.ldquoThrough HIE and Scottish Enterprise, the Scottish Government has made a commitment of over poundm towards infrastructure projects since .

title: nicola-sturgeon-told-stop-dithering-schools-plan-blended-learning-scrapped
story: The First Minister has softened her stance on the blended learning model being introduced by schools when they welcome students again in less than two months time ndash now labelling the idea a ldquocontingency.Camleys Cartoon: Call on schools reopening planTeaching unions have called on the Scottish Government and councils to resolve the situation ldquoin the interests of Scotlandrsquos pupils - while opposition politicians have accused the First Minister of ldquomonths of dithering on education.The Scottish Government has come under fire from parents and opposition MSPs for pupils to spend only part of the week in the classroom.When Ms Sturgeon set out her routemap for easing the lockdown in Scotland on May , she announced that ldquoall schools will re-open" from August ".She added: ldquoHowever, to allow appropriate physical distancing, children willto a blended model of part-time in-school and part-time at-home learning.Guidance issued to schools and councils by the Scottish Government a week later stated that the blended learning model is what ldquowe expect to see for a period of time.:MSPs warn teachers could face mountain of appeals over scrapped exams week before schools On Tuesday, Mr Swinney told MSPs that the the blended learning model ldquois the product of an agreement between the Scottish Government, local authorities, the teaching professional associations and parents.He added: ldquoIt has been worked on for some weeks since the lockdown began, to ensure that we had an agreed framework that could be deployed locally to maximise the impact and effect of education on young people.Speaking at First Ministerrsquos Questions, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe approach that we have decided that we must have in place as a contingency, with blended learning, is exactly what the United Kingdom Government is doing for England and what the Welsh Government is doing for Wales.Later, the First Ministerrsquos official spokesperson said that the blended model "has to be devised as a contingency", and stressed that ldquoitrsquos not where we want to end up but said ldquothese things are kept under constant review.The spokesperson added: ldquoIf we keep making progress in terms of the headline figures and numbers, we will get to a place where we are getting back, moving through the stages of coming out of lockdown as quickly as possible and wersquoll get back to a stage where we can hopefully get pupils and teachers back to full-time face to face school learning as soon as possible.:Nurseries to keep children in cohorts of eight amid social distancing re-opening plansScottish Conservative leader Jackson Carlaw pressed the First Minister on whether the Scottish Government ldquowill support local councils with the additional funding they require to adapt to the blended learning model.He added: "There have been soft words, matched by a record of non-delivery, with months of dithering on education.ldquoSo far, we have seen half-measures and buck passing, and parents are rightly furious.Nicola Sturgeon and Education Secretary John SwinneyldquoI ask the First Minister for a commitment - will she promise to commit the funds that are required, whatever it takes, to underpin a national endeavour to help councils get schools back in place and to give this generation of children the start in le that they deserve :FMQs as it happened: Nicola Sturgeon defends part-time re-opening schools plansMs Sturgeon stressed that local authorities should be using "creative" ways to restart face-to-face teaching but added that she ldquoabsolutely gives the commitment that,that involves additional resources to maximise school time, the Government will step in.She added: ldquoIf we have to have a model of education that is less than full time for safety reasons, for any period of time, we absolutely maximise that, and that we take steps to provide additional support to parents and young people for the periods that they spend out of school.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader. Willie Rennie, poked holes in Ms Sturgeonrsquos plans to partially re-open schools, pointing to concerns parents have over childcare when they are required toto work under the Scottish Governmentrsquos routemap to easing the lockdown.He said: ldquoPeople will be going back to work next week and they will need the support next week.ldquoThe Government has put parents in an impossible position because they cannot choose between their job and their children. The Scottish Government ramped up national health service capacity and pumped billions of pounds into businesses to keep them alive, but on education, our children and their parents are being left behind.ldquoWhy does the First Minister not accept that,she is asking parents toto work, she has an obligation to work out who is going to care for their children :Nicola Sturgeon: Schools could open with nearer normalityvirus fight continues on trackThe First Minister stressed that ldquoit is a global health pandemic that is putting people in an impossible position.She added: ldquoI will not say to any parent or teacher or anybody  across the country anything other than that this is incredibly dficult for them each and every day."This is not about an unwillingness to make resources available, it is about using resources properly to get the country, including schools, back to normal in a way that is sensible and does not put the health of children or others at risk, and that is what we will continue to prioritise.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard highlighted comments made by Scotlandrsquos Childrenrsquos Commissioner, Bruce Adamson, who warned that governments have ldquoan obligation to ensure that children can access their human right to education.Mr Leonard told the First Minister that ldquowe are in an education emergency.He added: ldquoChildren have a right to education, so we need to pull out all the stops to make sure that our childrento school safely and full time as soon as possible.:Nicola Sturgeon and Ruth Davidson in Twitter spat over Scottish Government adviserldquoScotlandrsquos teachers, parents and young people also want clarity, and this week they have had nothing but mixed messages. Anxious parents are writing to me about the impact that schools being closed is having on their children and the impact that the Governmentrsquos mixed messages are having as well.Teaching unions, who have called for more cash for councils to adapt classrooms, want clarity to be given to staff and parents, and are planning for the blended learning model to be adopted when schools begin to re-open.Larry Flanagan, general secretary of the EIS, said: ldquoTeachers are planning now for an Augustof pupils and that planning is based on a blended learning approach, as advised by the Government-led education recovery group.ldquoWith the health guidelines that are currently in place, including the two-metre social distancing requirement, it is simply not possible to have all pupils in school, safely at the same time.ldquoMore could be achievedthe Scottish Government funded councils to create more classrooms and to employ more teachers. The EIS would urge both layers of government to work together to deliver this, in the interests of Scotlandrsquos pupils."He added: ldquoClearly, the preference for teachers and parents alike would be for schools to be able to operate normally as soon as possible but that does not look likely for August .ldquoBlended learning, therefore, as a practical solution to the challenges presented by the Covid- crisis, is the operational plan for schools to restart.

title: last-clyde-built-sailing-tankers-return-home-major-boost
story: The former oil-driven bulk carrier was built in  by Russell  Co at their Bay Shipyard in Port Glasgow before Glasgow merchants Wright  Breckenridge dispatched the -metre ship to service their India and Pakistan routes.As the last iron-hulled four-masted sailing ship of her kind, after the loss of her nine sister vessels through war or shipwreck, the Falls of Clyde remains a key point of interest in Scotlandrsquos shipbuilding history, as well as a site ripe for development that would restore her to, and perhaps surpass, her former glory.: Coronavirus: Social care workers twice as likely to die from Covid as colleagues on NHS frontlineFalls of Clyde Internationalare a Glasgow-based team working tothe elegant but well-worn boat to Scotland to convert her into a carbon-free education and working vessel that they envision could become a link to ldquoforging strong ties between communities around the world.The not-for-profit group plan to offer opportunities to disadvantaged children and young adults to have an adventure of a letime and will be the first company in Scotland to offer carbon-free cargo transportation exporting Scottish goods and importing products back into the country.With ocean plastic waste continuing to rise, the FOC plans to trawl the sea as she sails, collecting ghost nets and plastic waste and recycling them onshore. The ship will be multi-al, carbon-free and, the team believe, is set to become an important social and historical landmark for Glasgow and Scotland.Now, in the latest development of the -year campaign that has seen the boat threatened with dismantling and dashing the hopes of campaigners who had planned to see her back in her birthplace last year, FOCI have secured the backing of a major company who will help modernise the ship.The ABB Marine  Ports will lead the main development of the ship as, making use of modern technology, as they take it from disrepair to a fully-al sailing ship through the design and implementation of the engine and propulsion system ndash and bringing the dream of ing the -year-old vessel to her homeland ever closer.Tim Munn, sales manager at ABB, explains ldquoABB Marine  Ports is delighted to be working with Falls of Clyde International in order to design and supply a power and propulsion system for the Falls of Clyde vessel.ldquoABB Marine  Ports, Falls of Clyde international and partners will collaborate on innovative solutions in order to make the Falls of Clyde a showcase for what can be done with modern technology on historic vessels.Plans include the addition of battery storage, wind turbines, and hybrid power as well as the reinstatement of her signicant sail power.Hopes for the Falls of Clydersquos future voyages will be a far cry from her former le as a workhorse that saw her transporting cargo such as lumber, jute, cement, and wheat from ports in Australia, Calornia, India, New Zealand, and the UK.In , Falls of Clyde was bought by Captain William Matson, a Swedish-born American shipping executive and the founder of Matson Navigation Company, taken to Honolulu, and registered under the Hawaiian flag.After a considerable redesign, she made voyages that saw her carrying oil, sugar, cargo and passengers between Hawaii and Calornia.She soon developed a reputation as a hardy, fast, and reliable vessel.:Opinion, Alison Rowat: Too many are suffering, time to get back in business, ScotlandDesignated a US National Historic Landmark in , the Falls of Clyde is crumbling in harbour, neglect showing on her hull, deck and masts.In  The Bishop Museum, former owners of the vessel, announced plans to sink her, before FOCI stepped in.But the latest development in the tale of repatriating the Scottish ship could signal her new le could now be imminent, after many years of uncertainty.David OrsquoNeill, founder and director of the project, said: ldquoFOCI welcomes the positive approach received recently from the offshore renewables sector in Europe to play a substantial part in helping us to put out a request to global players to help design, build and install an emission free-storage and propulsion system for the
